And please don't compare what you're talking about to animals. That's gross misrepresentation. Animals are food and if we were still hunting with Spears they'd be suffering more. Ahh, interesting.
Now, to be fair though, most western nation kind of have things like that for certain people. In America we don't have mandatory service but we all have to sign up for 'selective service' which is the system or lists (in its most basic form) that they'd use for a draft in the event one was required. It's called selective service because a pacifist isn't forced into the military. Whether it's a religious reason or a personal one if you are agains the violence you aren't forced to do so. But the government will sometimes try to put you in a homeland civilian service that supports the war (working in a factory or something in the event of a draft).
So, yes they are offered some protections but it's not so much just them or just Finland. It's a lot of Western countries that respect religion and the personal freedom of belief and expressing that belief.

Yeah the USSR is fascinating. And, while totally dystopian, absolutely built on the backs of the people. It really puts in perspective the currency of human life too.
and this is interesting about what's going on today...
http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/what-the-russian-protests-mean-for-putin

As long as the dog's loyalty to you is still strong and you can keep him in line I'll think we can overlook this.
lol, it's actually pretty wild though. Scary to ~~think~~ watch democracy gone awry and the authoritarian nature of the Russian Government. (We're returning to Greatness Comrade! Uncle Putin is leading us back to our Superpower position in the world! We were first to space! We had nukes! We were feared!)
When you think about it, and the book describes it a bit, that sentiment of working collectively as a country to be this 'great' superpower to then being where they are at now? It's gotta bruise not just the government and politicians but the average citizen who toiled in those factories.

It's really interesting. The book I recommend actually talks about things that are Samizdat, which was unofficial or dissident literature. There was another term, I think used to a degree for some official literature too.
But yeah the whole thing was really interesting. And for the record everything out of the First Bureau(?) that was censored never was critical of the Soviet Government. They would never say, we only installed gas in Moscow or 3 towns or something, you know?
But yeah all in all super interesting.

WRITING.TITLE: Curious about the immediate building of the Berlin Wall and if there were any escape? Also are their figures for the amount of migration East to West Berlin preceding the wall's construction?
WRITING.TEXT:
I'm curious how large of a population migration there was to prompt such a rapid building of the wall. My understanding of it was the border was closed and then the wall was constructed overnight. Did the creation of that border alarm East Germans? Even though it was overnight it strikes me as a large construction project, did people attempt to flee immediately prior to or during its building?
I looked up some of the answers here in the past. They sort of mention some parts. The building escape where the border ran down the middle of the street, the rapid construction of the wall and the date it was constructed. None of it offers too much detail though. Any further reading on this would be fine too if you don't have time to source and answer. Sometimes I feel like this should just be the history book club/recommendation list. That'd make a great newsletter for this sub. Week's topic with 2 good articles and a book recommendation.
Sorry, I have this horrible habit of phrasing questions as statements. I feel like, and in this forum it's more fitting, that posing a question on one niche topic sometimes loses sight of it within a larger context. Granted I can't expect you awesome people to write us encyclopedias (but if any of you are authors would love to read your book).
Thank you very much for any response I get. It's much appreciated what happens here and absolutely love the sub.

wild how far back people held ideas that turned out to have some truth to them on such a large scale.
Equally fascinating is the cult like thinking too. Man, human nature cray cray eh?

i jsut saw this. but i think in general there's been a lot of really good competition in most matches. look at the NCAA men's basketball, there's some not to competitive games and some really competitive ones.
Any tournament with 64 teams is going to have a few bad teams. Multiple teams from one school would be confusing and in a way offer an advantage to that school to win it. In a way this is esports but it's also college sports. As for the sister team there's nothing stopping you from having an eSports club and fielding a sub/scrim team that participates in amateur tournaments/open division and helps you practice. Even if they're just a practice/sub squad.
I think it's also important to realize the other squad was competing at a college level. And while I understand where you're coming from the nature of group/swiss or early tournaments are like there. Especially when you have such a large number of teams. A 4-1 gets eliminated and a 3-2 gets through. You can almost make the argument for any group stage. Well it's not fair! This really good team will move on and this one wont just because they were seeded based on when they won their spot or entry tournament.
I hear ya though. Mostly I bet it's for confusion purposes too. Having two teams in it would be weird for viewers, friends, family...people wouldn't know who is who.
It's really coming off as legitimate now and looks almost like the NCAA basketball tournament. That gives it a lot of credibility with people. And something to relate to. They know brackets and they know their school. So they know who to root for and who's 'their team'.

What he's conveniently forgetting to add to his scenario, and this is where you know it's an actual issue worth addressing, is that he talks of 'effecting your life' and 'rewards.'
If he wins 10, 20 or even 50 grand on one play, he's not playing 2500 anymore per daily play. His plays will up and up until he spends it all back of does some stupid short gamble and owes more than he's got back.
I played horses for a year to earn a living. It wasn't easy, lol. But the point is if you really want to take on risk and make some serious money it'll involve some degree of work and self discipline. You manage a budget and stuff. There's an exact term for it, I forgot but it basically comes down to money management when you're actually gambling for a living.
I want to tell all these guys to go play horses for a year and earn themselves a 50k net profit ytd. I'd like to see one of em do a profitable quarter, lol.

i think there's a difference though. gambling here isn't really gambling and it's just wasteful. like you could make some flag short calls and actually make some money, have some risk and still get a thrill.
if you really want to gamble, i would go to a casino where you can win some real money. It literally is throwing money away because you don't even know what your payout will be or remotely near it.
I played horses for a while. Semi professionally made a living off it. It was 'thrilling.' I'd never just put a bet down 'to have fun' with it.
That's crazy. I get it, it's your life, you do you. But there's a point there and it's a valid criticism. An expected one especially if you're not just going to do that but either brag about the winnings or mope about losing.

not sure if it's the arrogance or spoiledness that blows me away.
i'm sure being raised feeling blowing $2500 "betting" *on a stock* is in some realm of normal and okay is also raising a perfectly well adjusted adult.

Yeah there's a lack of understanding here a bit about how these sauces are used normally. And to a degree how they're used on the show, minus the dab.
When they mix a sauce for the wings at the further end of the spectrum they're using such tiny amounts to bring the heat up. I'm not even sure if they're good 'wing' sauces as much as they are for Jambalaya like dishes.
When they do that dab, I'm like in awe because it's just not meant to be consumed like that, let a lone on a single wing to boot.
I had it was either 357 or Blair's at a...beer convention? Or maybe a hot sauce thing. They had tortilla chips to taste sauces and then toothpicks to taste that one.
Like, you slide the toothpick in and out. So it's barely covered. Of course, and I'm thinking it's the beer convention we're at, I take a tortilla chip and blob that shit on there and eat it.
It legit felt like mustard gas or something. It's pain in the mouth, the face, the stomach, the esophagus. I actually helped my own alright. I mean I was fucked up but kind of tolerated it. It's a good 20 min of pain/discomfort though.
I don't really seek out the 'spiciest' kind of shit anymore. I guess after you do it it's like meh. I do enjoy my spicy food still, just prepared a bit more proper I suppose.
edit: I'm also a guy who has been using Dave's regularly for years in my cooking. Not as much anymore because tastes change and I've turned more to using peppers directly to cook.
That said, if people are curious and seeking this kind of shit out start with liek Dave's Insanity or something like that. It's, you really don't get it until you've tapped into that over the line kind of heat and you realize 100k or 500k? Why am I trying this?

Definitely. But I'm sure it isn't like a '30 foot training exercise with divers all around the sub like, 'we got you!'

Politics settles to the lowest common denominator. What's easiest. I didn't elect people to make easy fucking choices.
It's not easy, it's not pleasant. It's sure as fuck expensive. And there's not much about that I like. But I inherently feel, both economically, and as an unalienable human right we need to provide healthcare for people.
Right now, we provide it if you got nothing or a good enough job for it. And the only other option wants to be done away with. *When it's a private market oriented program!*
They already killed it when they did that. Forced the private market initiative on it.
Single payer is the way to do, hands down. IMO. Also no cheap. Not easy. But it's the most transitional and reasonable approach.
Part of me hates the small businesses mandates of Obamacare but if you set that standard then people will consider it while starting businesses. It becomes a standard to expanding past a point and to me, that's kind of okay.

I think what we need is to cap costs for poor and lower income individuals, shifts the burden to insured, wealth people. Or just wealthy insurance companies. The problem isn't insuring the uninsured. The problem is the rising cost of health care. The uninsured getting pummeled by this is the symptom.
I really don't have a good solution for this. Zilch in the idea department. Incentives for being healthy is a good one though. And making sure people use their bi annual or annual check ups. So they stop attending ER's for stupid shit. Throw in an educational campaign.
Capping costs though really is what it comes to. I'm a fiscal conservative in most areas but healthcare is one that people should have access to in the 21st century. So rolling back medicaid doesn't sit well with me. Nor do I think block grants are going to be effective. Let alone cheap.

Living well is the best, hands down. That said, I guess, it doesn't need to be out of spite. I think the point of that saying is that doing well for you is caring about you and not them.
I try not to take joy in other's misery. I guess. When it comes to someone I look at as an adversary though, I guess that changes.
Lol, yeah def does.
Might be decent book material if you write it right. Sounds like Gone Girl the real version.

I'm going to step in here and say addiction isn't the same.
The options offered to our addicts are shit and based, largely, even therapist who hold medical degrees, on AA. Which is just absolutely bonkers psuedo science.
And it's hard. It's *easy* in the sense everyone wants to help you. And thinking that person wants to keep on that path is really...it's a tough pill to swallow because it's not entirely true.
Waking up one day and deciding to get yourself help can be a pain in the ass. Much much harder than just buying drugs again. Methadone clinics needs proof of past treatment attempts and suboxone doctors only accept cash, let alone medicare/aid.
I'm not saying their aren't options and I'm not saying you should tolerate criminal behavior. And kicking them out isn't an easy thing to do. But wishing death?
I really don't know many people who feel that's a normal sentiment toward addiction.

it's part time, boredome, and craziness. when you got time you'll figure out the way to do what it is you want to do.

Thinking about this is weird. Like to get software to do that you need to already have an internet connection. Obviously could have had it at any point prior. Then everywhere they go, they take a day to brute force wps pins? At least my understanding of why it's weak.

I said how you feel about it because all you replied to me with was an opinion. Nothing to back it up. Just because you feel like it wouldn't work doesn't mean it won't or you shouldn't try.
Also, you're being dramatic again, Kidnapping? No, but they wouldn't be able to walk out of the store with the firearm until the background check cleared. The reality is, like a lot of security, the theater is half the battle. Criminals don't sign up for things that require checks or registration.
But yeah I think your claims that it's unrealistic or a fantasy are just misplaced. You lack an understanding of how it might work. Hell, without trying we would really never know. Ultimately, I don't see why you insist that a criminal, with an immigration investigation, wouldn't come up when buying a firearm. Or if the FBI did get notified Mateen was buying an AR in Orlando that they might not revisit him since he was on a watchlist twice.
Nor, when I suggested things a ten round magazine cap, federally, you just ignored it. Nor did you even begin to propose an alternative solution other than letting another shooting happen.
And really, you're straw manning like crazy. A strawman isn't an attack on your character. The argument you presented, without facts and saying "It won't work because this isn't T.V." actually is a strawman because you provided no reasoning to back that up. Because I'm not proposing television. I'm proposing running names against watchlists we currently maintain and open NICS for assault type weapons. Hell, apply the same things to hadnguns we do to rifles, that simple.
Dont' attack me. Your looking for calling what I said ad hominem which is also what you're doing by attacking me. I wasn't attacking you, because your argument was your opinion on something and isn't going to prove or advance any meaning in this debate.
Christ man. Use google at least.
And what kills me is the apathy. It's just you'd rather say, welp disagree! and move on! I offered yo ua shot to provide a different solution and even proposed shit like ten round mag limits. But you really just don't give a shit. You're worried about you and your ability to continue buying what you want to buy when you want it. It's selfish and immature. When there is 100% chance there will me another MCI shooting.

Nah man. I guess I'm not a community kind of guy. The best thing you could do for yourself is a get an editor. It can be a friend, if it's the type of friend you'd trust for something like...telling you your wife is cheating on you. And smart/good writer/editor.
i know that sounds dramatic but it needs to be the type of person you want there to tell you the whole truth. No matter how shitty it's gonna be to hear.
And the reality is people are always like, "constructive criticism" and I hate to be that guy, in the world of writing we tend to be pretty good at looking at each other as writers. Not black, white, asian, blue, green, man, women. But as a fellow writer. And in my group of writers, something we...partially opt to do by choice, victimization has no place. People need to hear shit like, get rid of that paragraph, stop going into so much background, cut this, and trash this character or rebuild them.
You kind of just don't find that in people out here. And when you ask for it...well, it's still, "You know, overall it's pretty good. I don't think I can relate to the character though. I'm not sure it's entirely believable he would just leave like that."
So what do you do? You go back and add a sentence "his cell phone rang, and he said 'I gotta bounce.'"
And do we ever really repost it again for more follow up? Nah. Long term collaboration with a trusted editor is wear it's at. And whatever else works for you (so in that case is the community does, all the more power to ya). Just not for me.

Holy shit man, you don't let em walk out of you store with a gun until it's done, don't care how glacially slow the government is to do it.
Sorry I touched on something a bit more real and jsut got back your solid opinion and a load of shit on why it wouldn't work. Sorry it bothers how you *feel* about it.
So you're telling me the guy who was under investigation by ICE about a marriage for a green card and had associations with the guys arrested for planning to kill soldiers wouldn't pop up on a background check? He's the one who bought the guns. The other guy didn't because he was probably scared shitless of all the jihadi shit he was looking up. THe guy in Orlando's name had been flagged before too.
It isn't every citizen, again, stop with the fucking dramatics. It's only if you want to take a damn similar gun home that our combat infantry use. You can walk out of a gun store with a damn near similar gun, with more dangerous ammo (HP), and more rounds than an Infantry man carries on a patrol.
Except you're not in combat. And someone will, again, shoot up some fucking mall or something.
Come on man, you're killing me. You're suggestion is that because it might not work anyway we shouldn't try. Frankly, it's weak at best and just bullshit at worst.
I'm sorry you're feelings are bothered by this. You're opinion that it might not work, so why try? Is no way to approach any fucking problem. Jesus. And don't call me an idiot. You've provided 0 evidence for this. I bet the same argument was put forth about the brady bill.
And part of, despite providing 0 evidence, what you're saying has a point. It won't stop everyone. It may not have stopped Orlando. The guy did buy a Glock and was background checked. In my opinion, it speaks more to the failure of the FBI to take him off their watchlist. It also incentives us to have stronger background checks. A federal law, a single one covering both handguns and rifles.
What frustrates me is you argue against it without providing an alternative. You know. It's the lack of trying. If I'm wrong, tell me the answer. Not doing anything, to me, is immeasurably wrong and, frankly, not the type of person I am.
For all the shit people put out here about being a gun owner to do something or a good guy with a gun beats a bad one. The lack of trying is hypocritical.
Even a magazine limit to 5 or ten shots. 100% that cop gets a shot on him.
And more so, even if Orlando happens because the background check sucks, San Bernardino probably doesn't. Cause the guy who bought the weapons was a criminal.
edit: and that's the point. you're working in absolutes. the absolute right now is that another shooting will happen. 100% sure of that. We both are. But if we could reduce the chances of it happening? By 20? 30? 50? 75%? by creating a stricter background check, you wouldn't do it?
glad i wasn't the only one looking at that and thinking unoriginality

No you have due process. If you want to own a weapon that our troops aren't trusted with taking home after deployment submit to the background check. Everyone does it for handguns because handguns are used in homicides. Now rifles are being used in MCI incidents, with some sense of regularity recently. Sure you could say the number of total people killed the last 6 years from these incidents is less than a 1000. You'd probably be right. Does that mean we shouldn't make it harder for he next guy to shoot up a mall and add another 50 to the list?
Those lists you're talking about already exist. We lost due process with the establishment of our secret courts and the patriot act. I'm only looking to help weed out the few truly bad actors that are using legal means to create terror.
edit: Trust me, I'm pretty torn about the current police state we live in. I'm reading articles about CBP forcing people to give the passwords to their cell phones and i"M like whaaatt the fuck man. On the other hand it feels like mass shootings are less common events but also events we shouldn't have to continue dealing with. Or attempt to hamper. Especially ones related to terrorism. It's not an easy pill to swallow either way. It's also incredibly important to maintain and exercise your rights. And to keep a keen eye on the law. Generally I like to think it isn't abused nearly to the extent it could be. Generally that seems to be the case. Most cops aren't the bad apples kind of argument.
Then again when I hear Trump bash 'the media' and wonder if he's willing to attack the first amendment and undermine it with falsehoods at what point would it end? I'm particularly skeptical in this political climate of alleviating ourselves of any rights less we lose them forever, or the slippery slope is hit and we tumble down it.

I do want to thank you for being clear about that and pointing it out. Def makes a bit more sense now and I just want to reiterate how much I disagree with a lot of the reasons and things they ban on Assault Weapons.
That said, generally illegal handguns are more expensive that counterparts that can be bought legally. Saying handguns are so widely available isn't really a good argument for it. Saying most homicides occur from handguns is, and it's to your point.
I was mostly just talking through how it's presented to someone who is voting on a bill. The length of the barrel really isn't going to change shit. The place that this argument really gets dangerous is when people say, "Oh well, 5 round, 15 round, 30 round mag! It doesn't make a difference he'll jsut reload it!"
Or handguns are prevalent and they have 12 or 15 round magazines, but you ban them from my AR? It doesn't make sense!
And frankly that's bullshit. High capacity magazines are great for...putting more rounds down range faster. What's the purpose of that? Oh to suppress someone. I firmly believe that in Orlando if the guy was limited to 5 or 10 round magazine the cop would have been able to effectively shoot back rather than hide behind a pillar as 223 put holes into the wall and probably the thought to the cop that, if me, my vest too.
And for anyone who claims home defense, buy a shotgun. Please. But if you insist 10 rounds is more then enough close quarters. Most people talk about this kind of shit without realizing these guns are designed to engage at 100, 200 meters. Let alone 20 feet.

Don't you think the point of the background check would be to say, "He had ties o these guys we arresed in 2014 for plotting to kill soldiers. He just tried to purchase an AR with 1000 rounds."
"Alright, bring his file back up, knock on his door, and check his communications."
No then he gets arrested. Border Control? They're U.S. citizens. Come on, are you nuts?
Saying it'll happen anyway is no excuse to not put the hurdle there. Especially if the hurdle involves a background check from intelligence/FBI/LEO resources. Get a grip.

did a bit a of journalism a few years ago. mostly fiction now. had representation for a book, going to take another stab this year with it.
got good feedback on it actually. just thought it might be hard to sell. i shopped it sort of after the circle came out and it's...not really similar but hits that BNW/1984 vein. Today? think it'll be great.
I half wrote that comment because I just don't like the peaches and cream description of writing. It always seems to fluff it up. And the idea of immersing yourself in your art or field, while sometimes necessary and always present to a degree is the exact opposite of what you need sometimes.
In my opinion, some people can write and other can't. I writer better when I"m reading more actively and sometimes I can't write at all until enough time has passed because it's influencing me too much. It's deeply personal thing, fiction, and treating it any other way seems uninformed, least from experience.

Due process applies in the courts not in capitalism.
And don't be so dramatic it's not abolishment. It's common sense. Sure there's no direct correlation between the Brady Act and safer streets but neither of those guys bought handguns to shoot shit up.
All I want is the hurdle to be there. And illegal guns are generally more expensive than their legal counterparts. Obviously. So let's add that hurdle legally for bad guys who, recently, looked at the legal purchase of a firearm to commit crime as the way to go. Let's make a guy who looks at Inspire think, will they know what I read? What I look at? Will they find those Facebook messages or that email?
Of course unless he's actually associated they won't but if he thinks it he won't bother.
